Alice Willardson

IT seems only yesterday that we had our annual "Day with Longfellow." I mean the day we spend each fall in the canyon. We sit on a hillside in the warm sunshine absorbing the quiet and glorious color while we take turns in reading Longfellow's poems. It has become a sort of personal holiday to keep the autumn from slipping past us.

This year the maple leaves were so colorful that with the sunlight on them they actually seemed to give off light and warmth like fire, fire which does not leap and fade but remains steadily brilliant. I am glad, too, for the pine boughs and the cedar berries, for today the sky is gray and the wind is furious. Dead leaves are blown carelessly against the windowpanes; the fire in the fireplace feels good. The smell of the pine boughs burning in the grate is so pungent that I can close my eyes and see the Christmas tree. I can see all the gifts and wrappings scattered everywhere and hear all the happy noises and excitement. It won't be long till Christmas! You know!

This year I think I'll have an apron Christmas! This morning the sewing room looks very cozy and inviting. And just last week I heard Vina say she didn't have a single good apron. She likes one that is big and serviceable. Kate likes them to be sort of pretty and serviceable, too. I have a pattern with a ruffle on the shoulders, pinafore style, that will give it a festive appearance. She likes red, too, and it will sort of go with her kitchen. Anne always loves yellow and I have those scraps of flowered dimity which will combine with either white or yellow organdy beautifully.

That's one thing about giving aprons; they can be so individual. And they are within the pocketbook of the giver and always welcomed by the receiver. There are so many styles, colors, and materials—aprons for all occasions and all ages. Apron styles like those in illustrations No. 1 and No. 2 will cover your whole dress from danger of splashings. Made from percale, and minus the ruffles, they will be very practical. If made from dimity, they wear exceptionally well, too, and are so pretty to protect your nice dress while you serve the Sunday dinner. With the ruffles, or a touch of applique, they are pretty as well as serviceable. Notice the back in picture No. 2.

If you are tired of washing and untangling apron strings, this button back is very neat and effective. And if you want to save ironing, leave off the ruffles and just trim with braid, bias tape, or a combination material. There are many other styles for anyone who wants an apron to really work in, one that covers the dress completely. Wrap-around styles are the handiest and most useful aprons for the busy housewife.

Next, there are all the lovely little serving aprons—aprons as pretty and dainty as flowers. These can be No. 4 made from lawn, dimity, organdy, dotted Swiss (and by the way, if you want a very fragile, dainty looking apron that will really stand many washings, you can't beat dotted Swiss). There are three pictures of serving aprons illustrated here, Nos. 3, 4, and 5, which can be made from combinations of materials. They allow you to use scraps of quite a variety of shapes and sizes. Often when you have to use your own ingenuity to make something of the material you already have on hand, the result is much prettier than if you had bought special material and used a commercial pattern. A combination of materials is usually prettier than just one material, and you can use old aprons for cutting patterns for new ones.

No. 6

APRON No. 6 gives a suggestion for using applique trimming to form the pocket. Applique is used also to trim No. 7. An excellent idea for getting flowers, fruit, etc., for your applique work is to cut them out from some of the many colorful materials with large and distinct designs.

Aprons may be effectively trimmed with ruffles of self material (as illustrated in No. 8) or they may be accented with ruffles of a contrasting color. A very lovely decorative apron was made from white organdy as illustrated in No. 9. Colorful flowers cut from percale were inserted under the hem. The hem was turned over the flowers and fastened down on the right side by a dainty featherstitch. The same motif was also sewed under the organdy pocket. The flowers under the organdy not only made the work less inclined to ravel, and more easily ironed, but they also gave it a sort of ethereal, fairylike touch so suitable to organdy.

No. 10

There are no gifts more acceptable to both mothers and daughters than the lovely pinafores illustrated in No. 10. Make the "daughter" apron out of material just like mother's.

There are all types of trimmings, too. Braids and laces of all kinds are on the market now. There are all kinds of handwork, from blanket or featherstitching to lovely embroidery done in silk.

And, if you feel so inclined, there are now available fabric paints which are suitable and absolutely washfast. I have a painted tea towel which washes right along with my dish towels regularly.

If you are looking for something really different, there are all the aprons for special work, like clothespin aprons and sewing aprons. I even got an idea for a man's apron the other day as I watched my son priming the car. Why not make an apron of heavy, waterproof material, containing pockets for the sponge, the cleaner, the wax, the chamois, etc.? Might save a lot of hunting for them. This apron could be hung in the basement after it was used and it would be ready for use again the next time, complete with all the equipment.

Maybe I'm planning a gift that would be more welcomed by the man than by my gift that way, it's an idea!

ANDREW wanted to be married at once, but Margaret wanted a beautiful wedding. At the store when they could not pay her in cash, she got many yards of lovely material, and sometimes whole bolts of lace. She wanted some bonny and dainty things for herself and for her home.

In Scotland the girls began early to make and plan their trousseaux. Kathleen and Mother were wonderful sewers, and with their help, they all could have beautiful dresses, and she could have some lovely things for her home. So she left the spinning room in the cabin for a sewing room at Mother's for a time.

They baked a wedding cake, fruit puddings, and shortbread, everything that was essential for a very wonderful wedding. And while they worked they talked.

Kathleen and Mother told Margaret of the time when Andrew had raised grain on the river bottoms and timbered in the forest and that when he received word of Jane's marriage he hadn't gone back to the fields or to the forest.

"Yes, he was hard hit for a time, my darling, but his mission has cured him of all that," Mother said.

Margaret remembered the "Jane look," as she had called it on the plains when Andrew would sit for a long time and look far beyond the camp. She had known he was dreaming of Jane. That was all passed now; she did not need to worry about Jane. Margaret knew now that Andrew loved her. Yes, Andrew loved her but why did he not go back to the land and to the forest? The wool was her job. Andrew's was the harvest and grain. She thought of a plan.

She was curious, and wanted to go to the river bottoms with Andrew Rumgay. She suggested to him that they take a horseback ride the next Saturday afternoon. She was tired of being shut up in the sewing room; she wanted to get out in the sunshine.

Andrew thought it was a wonderful idea, so he brought Gypsy and Pinto up to Mother's for their ride.

They slowly walked their horses to the canyon. Resplendence was beautiful at this time of year. A tapestry in every tone and color of the autumn had been hung from the ceiling of the mountains. Farther up in the hills, vesper campfires were bright burning. The river sang low, sacred melodies for the rituals of the harvest time.

They tied their horses to some maple brush and walked into the great silent woodlands. Higher up in the mountains they heard the loud crash of falling trees and the wild cry of timber.

"The more trees that come down in the forest the more homes go up in the valleys. Many people are coming to the mountains to find homes every year, Margaret. They must find them. Soon I must return to the forests."

They walked back to their horses, mounted, and when they reached the river road Margaret touched the reins with her quirt, and they were off to a gallop towards the bottoms. At the crossing they reined their horses. Margaret was off Pinto in a jiffy. They stood almost speechless in the beauty of the valley and listened to the wild singing of the stream. They found a boulder on the edge of the creek and sat down.

ANDREW was particularly interested in the songs of the stream. He smiled.

Can you imagine anything so far-fetched as to interpret these very happy roundelays of music into weird and solemn dirges?
"Oh, it's so peaceful here. Wouldn't it be wonderful to live out here? You could farm and I could card wool. When you harvested I could bind and gather the sheaves."
"When the Indians become more friendly, Margaret, we will build our home in the bottoms." Andrew arose and led Margaret to the fields. The one hundred sixty acres had been raised on some of it this year. He picked up some of the fine black soil, pressed it in his hands, and slowly let it fall back to mother earth.
"I am like my kinsmen in Scotland, Margaret. I would like to own some land."
Margaret gave a big sigh of relief. "We will find other fields, darling, and build greater harvests. The bottoms have wonderful dreams of home, wife, and children. Margaret, life will be so complete."
The young lady looked up and smiled. "Brother Rumgay, did I remember to tell you that I love you, and I think you are wonderful?" She put her arms around him and kissed him. "Name our wedding day, Andrew, and I will make arrangements to be there."
On their way home Andrew spoke seriously. "Margaret, we have treasure on our land, but we will never hang on the wall or place on the mantel." They walked into the plains one day.
"They are more precious than the crown jewels of Scotland. Mother has her rocks, the sage, ginger tea, even the catnip. Then what comes, Margaret?"
"Her prayers and faith, Andrew. I know that my Redeemer liveth."
"With such a wife, darling, I know I cannot fail." They planned to be married as soon as arrangements could be carried out. They would take two covered wagons for the wedding trip to the temple, and all the Macs, and this time the bairns.
One afternoon Andrew left his wagon up at Mother Mac's, for the women to pack everything they would need on the trip. They expected to leave at five the next morning. In the evening he went along to see that everything was ready. Bob was just putting in the wagon box the table and benches he had chopped to build fires.
"What, no Bob to build the fires?" Andrew asked.
"Mother is taking everything we used on the plains--tents, camp kettles, dishes, bedding, and this time we have a lantern."
"Mother says we are just now finishing up the trek, attending to the business that should have been taken care of years ago."
"Your mother has something there, Bob. Why didn't she mention it to me? How are the boxes? Mine are full. I can trust your mother."
"Well, that part won't be just like the plains," Bob gratefully admitted.
The Macs had planned to hold a reception at Mother's when they returned, but the people of the ward had taken things over. The meetinghouse was decorated, and the sisters had cooked a big wedding supper at the Hunters. They had baked other wedding cakes, as one would not be enough for everyone in town to have a piece. After the supper there was a wonderful program, and at the last Brother Huntcraft had a few words to say to Andrew and Margaret.
"I'll only keep you a few minutes. I know you all want to dance. I'd like to find a word Angus started. Andrew, a few years ago you and I picked out some land on the river bottoms.
"Well, after you left on your mission, the people decided that since you were so willing to go into the world and represent us, they would like to do something for you. Tonight we are giving you back the one hundred and sixty acres, all paid for, and nearly all broken up. And this is just one of the many wedding presents the people of Resplendence are giving to you tomorrow night, Brother and Sister Rumgay. A long and happy married life!"
Andrew felt he had the world in his arms when the Lord gave him Margaret. Now, with the land, and the many gifts his friends had showered upon them, he was amazed.
They called for a speech, and Andrew stood up. "Brothers and Sisters, my heart is too full for expression tonight. When a man has the gospel, a wife, home, land, beautiful gifts, and kind friends, no words can express his appreciation. I hope through my life and the rest of my life to prove to the Lord, and to you, how grateful I really am. Thanks a lot, folks."
At the end of the party they passed the wedding cake. Everyone called for a dance by the Macs. The orchestra began playing "Annie Laurie." Brother Coleman danced with Mother Mac, Bob chose Helen Hunter who was just about a Mac.
Margaret was beautiful in her white wedding gown and long veil of white, soft lace, which she had made, sewing yard after yard, upon row until it was long enough to fall into the full, rippling folds of her dress. She wore a wreath of white satin rosebuds with blue and ivory centers. Her corsage and bouquet were of white and pink lady slippers combined with blue sisters.
Kathleen was lovely in a beautiful shade of yellow. Mother, with the softest of blue hair, was very bonny in pale lavender. Janet, the little flower girl, wore pink.
The strains of the romantic music of "Annie Laurie" were changed to the sweet rhythm of "Home, Sweet Home." Everyone took partners and joined the Macs in the last dance. The music was sacred, the theme divine, as the bridal couple kept time to its beautiful melody.
"I love the cabin down on the millrace, Margaret," Andrew spoke softly.
"I have learned to love it too."
They danced a few measures, and Margaret added, "And the bairns."
Andrew waited breathlessly until Margaret spoke. "And you, too."

Packaged fresh fruit, containing oranges, lemons, or grapefruit, with a liberal sprinkling of nuts, is another idea. Put these (fruits or vegetables) in large containers which can be used later. Dish drainers, lettuce drainers, or anything which appeals to your imagination can be used.

"But, 'Lean your ear this way,' Saint Nicholas! No matter how good a job you line up—from this year on, you'll have to count on assuming the role of Santa Claus, permanently."

LIVING TO ENJOY THE BLESSINGS OF THE LORD 833 Living to Enjoy the Blessings of the Lord (Continued from page 800) before you, in the not far distant future, the possibility of a building, a women's building, erected by the generosity and self-sacrifice and faith and devotion of the women of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, that will be the equal, I am sure, of any building that women use in all the world as a women's building. So I congratulate you on your possibilities, on your probabilities, because I think in the not far distant future, if the world will come to its senses, if they will stop quarreling with one another, people will stop fighting one another and do more praying and less fussing, I think we can begin the erection of our building for the Relief Society that will not only give joy to you who are particularly interested, but all the rest of us will be happy that you have it.

We have been doing a lot of repairing of one kind and another, been working on this organ, making that a little better than it was before, that is, we hope we have. I have not been listening to it lately, but I am assuming that it is very 'much improved, and when they get it finished I am sure we will all be happy. But think what it means. Here you are. You have come into this greatest of all houses of worship. "There is not anything else like it, no other house in the world with a dome like this, no other house in the world that has the acoustics that this building has, and in this building we have one of the loveliest organs that anybody has in all the world. And wonderful choirs sing here. The voices of our Father's sons and daughters are heard here. It does seem to me when we sing if we would just appreciate how good he has been to us, it ought to be the easiest thing in the world to sing his praises while we are here in this marvelous building.

Blessings of Saints As I look over the audience I see the children and the children's children of some of those who were pioneers, came into this valley in an early day, and they came here with the word of the Lord in their hands. They not only had the Old and the New Testament, the Holy Bible, but they brought with them the Book of Mormon, the Doctrine and Covenants, the Pearl of Great Price, and other scriptures, all that the world has in the way of true scripture we have, plus a lot of other scripture that the world has not had until the Lord gave it to us. Surely we are not unmindful of all these things.

And when I think of the beautiful block that we are on here, and the flowers and the shrubs and the trees, the glorious sunshine that we enjoy here in this part of the world, and all of the blessings that God has bestowed upon us in such a rich way, and our homes, I am extremely grateful. Do you realize that when the people came into this valley, a little over one hundred and one years ago, there was not a house that a human being could live in? Now look at it. Lovely homes, lovely churches, streets, conveniences of almost every kind you can think of.

I cannot think
of a convenience that is important in all the world that we do not have
right here in this valley that a hundred and one years ago was a desert.
And when President Brigham Young looked over this valley and said: 'This is the place,' I can imagine that there were people in that group of 143 men, three women, and two children, who thought he must be dreaming. They could not imagine that this could be the place the Lord wanted them to settle.
But it was, and see what has happened.
And now, people come from all parts of the world to see what has been accomplished here in the last hundred years. Hardly a week passes that somebody does not come into the office who has never been here before and says, "This is one of the most beautiful cities as you have here."
Promises to the Righteous
Now, all the blessings that have come to us, brothers and sisters, are the result of keeping the commandments of God. All these blessings are not the result of our willfulness, our carelessness, or our indifference, but they are the result of honoring God and keeping his commandments, and there have been enough of our people who have saved the day for the rest.
You will remember in the days of Sodom and Gomorrah, when Abraham pleaded for two great cities that they be not destroyed because the people were so wicked, and when he asked: "Why would you not destroy the righteous people who are there in those cities," and the heavenly personage said to him: "No, not if there are enough of them."
Then Abraham began to plead. "If there are fifty people in those two great cities can they all be saved?"
"Yes."
"Forty?"
"Yes."
"Thirty?"
"Yes."
"Twenty?"
"Yes."
"Ten?"
Yes.
That is how precious righteous people are. Let us not forget that.
If there had been ten righteous people in those two great cities, and they were populous cities, the fire would not have come down from heaven to destroy them, but they would have had another chance.
Now, think of what we have here. Think of the righteous men and women that live in the community that you live in, and they are righteous. They are not perfect. I do not know any perfect people, but I have known some that it seemed to me were just as near perfect as it was possible to be. That is what the Lord has promised. If you seek first, not last, but seek his kingdom and his righteousness and all other things will be added that are worthwhile. That is what he means.
And think what we have. Think of the peace and quiet enjoyed here today and in some parts of the world bombs may be dropped any moment, guns may begin firing at any time. Why? Because the difference being, here we are trying to do what our Heavenly Father would like us to do and there, many of them are doing what they know they should not do.
Now, my brethren and sisters, and particularly the sisters, because you are the majority in this great audience today by far, I congratulate you. I congratulate you on belonging to the finest organization in all the world, officered, managed, and planned and carried on by women. There is not anything else like it, and I hope that you will keep in mind the suggestion of one of your sisters today to look after those who are not taking advantage of their opportunities. Do a little missionary work wherever you are and encourage others to do the same thing, and instead of having a few thousand people who are willing to do what the Lord wants them to do and make every effort to do that, there will be millions of people who are influenced to keep the commandments of God and stay the destruction that the Lord has said will come upon the earth unless the people repent of their sins and turn to him. He has already assured us that it will take repentance.
I would not like to sound a discordant note here, nor cause anybody to begin to worry because of the destruction that may come, but I can say this that the Lord has promised you in the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints that if you will seek first his kingdom, that all desirable things will be added. That means the undesirable things will be stayed and your homes will be the abiding place of peace and thanksgiving and gratitude to God, and mothers and fathers will love one another and work together in rearing their families. Parents will cherish their children and bring them up in the nurture and admonition of the Lord, and children will be taught to honor father and mother with the assurance that their days may be long in the land that the Lord our God gives unto us.
Gratitude for Hospitality
I have just touched upon a few of the things that the Lord has promised to us and to all people who will accept him and his advice. I think it is marvelous. I want to take this occasion to thank you, good women living in different parts of the country, who have taken care of us who are General Authorities of the Church as we have traveled through the country; we have been in your homes. You have fed us; you have given us places where we could be made comfortable, and in many cases you and your husbands have carried us on our way. I am grateful to you for the kindness that I have received.
It has been marvelous to me how many times I have been in a position where I needed real help, and it has come as a result of good women and good men in the community where I happened to be.
Now, coming back to the building, I wish we could tell you right now when it can be started. I wish we could tell you just when a number of them could be started. We are needing buildings for the Church in so many cases. We were in need of over four hundred houses of worship and structures to be used by the Church a year ago, and it may interest you to know that over two hundred of them are already finished or are in the course of completion.
Half of them, but there are yet another two hundred and more, and in so many cases where two communities or three use the same house for worship, in due time each will have its own house and its place of recreation, and all will meet together as brothers and sisters under the influence of the Spirit of the Lord.
How wonderful it is to have that influence. Come into this building when there is not a soul here and close your eyes and I think you will feel like others have.

Time after time people have said there seems to be an influence here that I have never felt any place else. There should be. There should be an influence in this building that people can feel because the Lord has promised that his Spirit will abide in these places that have been dedicated to him as long as we treat them as we ought to. I congratulate you. I wish I had words to express my appreciation for what you are doing, what has been done by those who have preceded you and for what your daughters who are coming along will do even after you are gone. What an opportunity the Lord has blessed us with, to give us the fulness of the earth in these marvelous mountain vales, and all the advantages and opportunities of the civilization of our day, plus the testimony that burns in the souls of hundreds of thousands of people that we are the children of God and we know it, and if we are righteous, may remain close to him throughout the ages of eternity. I congratulate the leadership of this great organization, your presidency and general board, the stake officers, and the ward officers. If you could get them all together this block would not hold them, to say nothing of this building. They are a great army of women and when you realize that at one time ten righteous people could have saved Sodom and Gomorrah from destruction, think what an influence you have, think what power you have in this world if you are recorded among those who are righteous, honoring God and keeping his commandments. It will not be long before disaster will come to the earth. It will not be very long before this earth will be cleansed and purified by fire and become the celestial kingdom, but in the meantime, the Lord has given to us the opportunity to go forward, rear our families, develop our homes, prepare our institutions of learning and all the advantages, under the influence of the same spirit, if we will, that will be here when our Heavenly Father and Jesus Christ, our Lord, will be here in person. Think what a wonderful thing it is! That is the preparation for it, that is why these commandments were given and the other commandments of the Lord, not to prevent us from happiness, but to add to our joy and our comfort and our satisfaction, day by day, while we go forward looking to the time when we will be with those whom we love forever. As I stand here today I realize it may not be long until the summons reaches me. When it comes I will pass out of the picture here in mortality, but when that time comes I am looking forward to meeting the dear ones that have preceded me, those who have gone before. And LIVING TO ENJOY THE BLESSINGS OF THE LORD there are many of them on the other side that have gone through the experiences of mortal life, have lived true and faithfully and devotedly, so that our Heavenly Father has promised them they may return to earth as celestial beings and dwell here throughout the ages of eternity. That is what these books are for. That is why the Lord gives us so much information that we refer to as scripture. It is not that we may have food and clothing and houses and lands here. That is only a part of it. It is that day by day we may so adjust our lives that we will become more perfect as the years go by, rear our families to be more perfect. That is the purpose of it all, in order that all may be saved in the celestial kingdom and have the companionship of those who are dear to us, forever. Relief Society for All the Sisters That is what this great organization you belong to was instituted for. It was not just to make quilts. It was not just to go from door to door and ask people to make a contribution to your fund. That was only a part of it. The Relief Society of this Church was organized that all of the daughters of our Heavenly Father, I say all of them, because it was intended that they should, those who are worthy should be identified with the Relief Society of the Church, and that each one should not only be a member but that each should be a faithful, devoted daughter of the Lord, working in that organization of Relief Society for the blessing of all your sisters. What an influence you have in the world, and how much more influence can be had if you can persuade your sisters in the communities in which you live, that are not doing anything particular in preparation for eternal life in the celestial kingdom, to come into the fold and begin work. I have been talking about the sisters, inferring that there are some women that are not yet doing all they should in the Church, but I would like to say to the two or three or half a dozen brethren that are here, we have a whole group of men in the Church whom unless we can get the sisters to help us, I do not think we will get very far with. We have men in the Church who have grown up in it, who do not even hold the Priesthood and we have others who ought to hold the Melchizedek Priesthood who only hold the Aaronic Priesthood, hundreds of them, and if they die under those circumstances they may lose their opportunity of eternal life in the celestial kingdom, and they are your brothers and husbands and fathers, in some cases. I do not mean you who are sitting here, but I mean the women, husbands and fathers and brothers, these men, and we need to do teamwork, and we need to set our homes in order. If our sisters would only encourage their husbands to do their part, visiting in the wards in which they live as ward teachers, trying to draw the men in that have not done just what they should, and then the women would go out and do their share, encouraging the women to come in. Do you realize what the Lord has said? What matters it though you spend your whole life here upon earth, performing the duties incident to mortality, spend your whole life, and during that time the result of your effort is the salvation of one soul, and that your own? He said you shall have great joy in our Father's kingdom with that soul. We all have something to do, and I congratulate you on what you have done.

No other group of women in all the world has compared with what you have done in the way of blessing mankind, rearing your families and devoting yourselves unselfishly to bringing peace and happiness to those that were in distress, and because of that, the Lord loves you, and he is anxious that you should have every advantage and every blessing, and he will give it to you just as fast as you are worthy. I am grateful to be here with you today. I thank these sisters who invited me to come and visit with you, and I want to be among those who will be permitted to come into your new building when it is completed. I hope that it may be kept so sweet and clean and wholesome and beautiful and delightful that the Spirit of the Lord will find comfort there. That is what I hope it to be, and I trust that that will be in the not far distant future. I wish I could tell you just where it could be located. I wish I knew, but it will not be far away from the Temple. It will not be far away from the Tabernacle, and I want to say to you it will not be very far away from the Lord, and that is the important part. So keep smiling, keep working, keep planning, and praying. Remember your sisters in the old world, millions of them, who have comparatively no comforts. In twenty-four hours they could not enjoy the peace that you have here in five minutes in this building today, wherever they are, and they are your sisters. We have over five thousand missionaries in the world endeavoring to bring the peace and happiness that you have to our Father's other sons and daughters. A good many of those in the world are women. There was a time when our sisters did not go into the world very much as missionaries. There was a time when some of the mission presidents did not think they could do missionary work very well, it was so difficult, but if you would see some of the letters that are written in from mission presidents now, "Cannot you send us some of those fine women that can do such splendid work among the women and among the children in these lands?" There is a way. It is coming. In the not far distant future there will be more missionaries out. If we will just keep the standard of liberty and of righteousness floating here in our homeland, keeping our homes in order, husbands faithful and devoted to wives, and wives faithful and devoted to husbands, parents to children, children to parents, neighbors to neighbors, remembering that the second great commandment referred to in this wonderful volume by the Savior of the world was: "Thou shalt love thy neighbor as thyself." If we did that how wonderful it would be to go from house to house and from village to village and find dwelling in every heart the Spirit of God burning there in a luminous, delightful way, filling the soul with happiness and peace and comfort and satisfaction and knowing that that will endure forever. I pray that the Lord will bless LIVING TO ENJOY THE BLESSINGS OF THE LORD these presiding officers, the general officers, the stake officers, the ward officers, all these who have responsibility, and oh, let your light so shine that others seeing your good works will be constrained to glorify the name of our Heavenly Father. We are his children. This is a part of his family that is gathered here today. How wonderful it is to know that he is not far from us, that he is all-powerful, and has promised us that if trouble comes, if necessary he will come down in heaven, not from heaven, he will bring heaven with him upon this earth and fight our battles and preserve us, and we will go on living throughout the ages of eternity. That is the promise of our Heavenly Father.

| Again, I thank you for your kindness to me and to my associates as we travel in your communities, your kindness to all those who need you, your kindness to those people who live across the great and mighty ocean. I do not know whether you have been told, but probably you have, one hundred and twelve carloads, each car the capacity of forty tons, a hundred and twelve carloads of food and bedding and clothing have been shipped across the ocean 839 since the war to feed and make comfortable your other brothers and sisters, some of whom have not yet come into the Church. That has been your contribution. How many quilts did you have? We have had in total about nine thousand. My goodness! Just about two months from now you will wake up some morning, somebody has left the window open and the fire has gone out and you will wish you had just one more quilt, and then realize that the organization that you belong to, in that one item—that is only one item—over nine thousand handmade, homemade, quilts have been made by your organization, and then you have asked for the privilege of giving them, not selling them 'of giving them to our Father's other children that they may be, in part at least, as comfortable as you are. God bless you for your faith and your devotion and your fine work. Keep your homes in order. Keep the adversary away. Live so that the Spirit of God will be with you all the time, and I can say to you that if you will do that you will be happy all the time and that you may so be, I humbly pray, in the name of Jesus Christ. Amen.

ONE LONE STAR
Dorothy J. Roberts

I shall be there; I must return
Tonight when one lone star will burn
Across the acres of the world.
Before its last faint gleam is furled
I shall follow the camel's hoof;
See winter silver on the roof;
And set my heart attune to hear—
Despite the centuries—one clear Hosanna,
Filtered though it be, coming from hilltops far from me.

I shall breathe the scent of myrrh
Blent by the kneeling worshipper;
And behold the jewels spread
Beside one on his humble bed.
With all the hungering hosts of men,
I shall partake of peace again.
Before the waning year is spent
I shall return for sacrament.

title: The Annual General Relief Society Conference
content:
the Annual General Relief Society Conference, Thursday, September 30, 1948). Could witness this picture as I see it. In no other place can it be seen but here, not only to see but to feel the influence of the Lord that pervades this building. I am looking into the faces of women from many parts of this country, and some from other lands, every one is a daughter of our Father in heaven. Is it not worth something to know that? Is there anything else that you can think of that would give you more satisfaction than to know that you are a child of our Father in heaven, and that he has given you the opportunity to live on the earth at this period of time when the gospel has been restored? 'That was only 118 years ago. That does not mean very much in the long period of time in the world's history, but think what has been accomplished in that time. How marvelous are the changes. When the Prophet Joseph Smith was born, he came into a humble home, a humble father and mother, but they were real Christians. His mother loved the truth and she loved her children. So Joseph, when he was just a boy, had the guidance of one of our Father's choicest daughters. I wonder sometimes as I travel throughout the country and see the hundreds of thousands of people Page 796 I wish everybody in the world scattered everywhere, how many of them there are that realize that they are the children of the Lord. He is the Father of our spirits. And how wonderful it is to live in this day and age of the world among a group of people who know that fact.

We are in this great building that was erected during the poverty of the people. They did not have steel to use as we have today. They did not have the electric lights. There are many things that we enjoy today that they did not have, but they built the greatest Tabernacle, the greatest house of worship in many respects, that has been built since the world began, and we are permitted to worship here.

Think of it, sisters. We have no way of measuring the blessings of the Lord unless we live so that we can enjoy them. We have been told here today that there are certain requirements that we must observe if we are to enjoy all that we should enjoy. And by the way, I believe I would like to turn here to one of the early books of the Bible and read to you what the Lord said, not in the beginning of time, but in the beginning of the peopling of this earth, when there were comparatively few on the earth. People did not know a lot of things that they know now. They did not understand the purpose of many things, but the Lord in his mercy began in the very beginning to give the people advice, his advice. He was not guessing about it because he knew.

Sometimes we give advice and I fear we just guess about it, but I am thinking now of the condition of the world after nearly six thousand years that the people have lived upon it, and the sorrow and distress and anxiety that exist. There never has been a time in the world when people knew as much as they know now. There has never been a time when there were as many comforts enjoyed by the people. It is marvelous what has been coming into the world all this time, and yet I think I am safe in saying that the majority of all the Lord's children who have lived upon the earth have fallen short of being what he wanted them to be.

But there was no justification for not following his advice and benefiting thereby because they had his commandments from the beginning. The Ten Commandments Let us consider for a moment some of the Ten Commandments. "Thou shalt have no other gods before me." Why should we? The Lord did not say we may not, but he said we shall not choose who is God, and there is no other god that can take his place. He is our Father. He has been the Father of all the people that have lived upon the earth, the Father of their spirits.

All of us have that wonderful blessing that we trace ourselves back to our Heavenly Father. And then he says: "Thou shalt not make unto thee any graven image, or any likeness of any thing that is in heaven above, 797 or that is in the earth beneath, or that is in the water under the earth: Thou shalt not bow down thyself to them." In other words, anything that we may propose, other than our Heavenly Father; we may call it what we will, but it does not become God and we may worship it, but we will not be benefited by doing so. And he says: "I the Lord thy God am a jealous God, visiting the iniquity of the fathers upon the children unto the third and fourth generation of them that hate me." Not only does the sorrow come to the individual in the first generation of those who hate him, but he says that it passes on to the third and fourth generation. How foolish we are, then, not to pay attention to him who is the Father of us all and who loves us and is anxious that every one of us should enjoy the kingdom of heaven, and how foolish we are if we listen to the suggestions and intimations and counsel of those who are not of God and who do not know what he knows.

Now he says further: "Thou shalt not take the name of the Lord thy God in vain; for the Lord will not hold him guiltless that taketh his name in vain." Think of the profanity that is in the world today, the carelessness with which the name of our Heavenly Father is used, and yet the Lord warned our fathers several thousand years ago that we were not to take his name in vain. He says further: "Remember the Sabbath day, to keep it holy." Why should we keep the Sabbath day holy? There are blessings that attach to us if we observe the Sabbath day and if we fail to observe it we lose our blessing, yet the majority of our Father's children who live upon this earth today, in this dispensation, do not honor the Sabbath day as our Heavenly Father has advised them to do. And what will be the result, what has been the result? The result has been the loss of many blessings. As our sister was telling us a few moments ago, we may not pay much attention to this thing, but if we expect to enjoy the blessings of our Heavenly Father, we must observe the law that governs that blessing. He has told us that.

So, today, think of the condition in the world in regard to the Sabbath day. It is not what the Lord has advised, but it is what people wish to do who love pleasure more than they love God.
I might go on and say: "For in six days the Lord made heaven and earth, the sea, and all that in them is, and rested the seventh day; wherefore the Lord blessed the Sabbath day, and hallowed it."
Just think what a wonderful world this would be if one day in seven all of our Father's children, your brothers and sisters and mine, would keep the Sabbath day holy. The power that would come into the lives of the human family cannot be measured or estimated. It would be marvelous what a change would occur in this world, because, not only would they enjoy the result of honoring the Sabbath day, they would close to our Heavenly Father on his holy day, but their minds would be expanded to think of righteousness on the other days, and
the world would be a different world in which to live.

Now he says: "Honour thy father and thy mother: that thy days may be long upon the land which the Lord thy God giveth thee."
There is a promise. What a wonderful thing it is to feel that we have lived, if we have, honoring father and mother, to be entitled to have our days prolonged. That does not seem a very difficult thing for us to do, to give honor and consideration and kindness and love to those who were the means of bringing us into the world. Surely it ought to be the simplest and easiest thing in all the world, and yet, I am afraid that even among our people, there are men and women who ignore that wonderful piece of advice, to honour father and mother, and in dishonoring them or failing to recognize them as they should, the blessings that they would desire and they might enjoy pass by them.

The Lord says: "Thou shalt not kill." In other words, thou shalt not take life. Just think of what that means, and think of today. You take your daily papers and pick them up and read the headlines and see in all parts of the world where the messages have come from, how many people are losing their lives because of the selfishness of somebody else who is anxious to enjoy and take from them what they have.

Now the Lord says: "Thou shalt not commit adultery."
I wonder if we realize what a terrible thing it is to violate that advice of Heaven's Father. Many people have an idea that it brings to them pleasure and satisfaction, and yet it brings to them sorrow and sickness and death. The Lord has warned us, long, long ago, and yet the world today is in the condition that it is in, very largely because our Father's other children, his sons and daughters, will not pay attention to his advice and counsel and the result is unhappiness—death to hundreds and thousands of people in this world who ought to be filled with happiness and satisfaction all the time.

Now: "Thou shalt not bear false witness against thy neighbour."
I wonder if we realize that if we tell a story about our neighbor, if we refer to our neighbor, if we say something to injure him, not telling the truth, that we violate one of the loving counsels of the Father of us all. He said we should not do that, and if we do, we do not gain anything, we always lose.

Now he says: "Thou shalt not covet thy neighbour's house, thou shalt not covet thy neighbour's wife, nor his manservant, nor his maidservant, nor his ox, nor his ass, nor any thing that is thy neighbour's."
In other words, we should not be selfish and try to obtain and take from others that which belongs to them.

I have just been reading to you some of the paragraphs of advice of your Father and mine. I have just been calling your attention to the fact that this I have read to you today has been in print for thousands of years. People all over the world do not have the Bible as we have it, but they have access to it in most parts of the world, and among all the wonderful things that are contained in this marvelous record that I hold in my hand, I have just read about ten simple things,
counsels of our Heavenly Father, that, and this I want you to remember, that if we observe, if the people of the world observe these commandments there would be no war, there would be no hatred, there would be no sorrow, compared to what we have in the world today, and the ten counsels of our Heavenly Father who knoweth all things, and we have had it all the way down through the ages, and the result is that because we have failed to pay attention to it, this world is in the condition it now is in, and you do not know, nobody knows, how soon another world war may be started, and if we have another, how much more serious it will be than anything else we have ever had.

Well now, in the days of the Savior, at least in the days of John the Revelator, he heard a voice and that voice said: "Come out of her, my people, that ye be not partakers of her sins, and that ye receive not of her plagues."
That was the voice from heaven that came to him. Do you know that is why you are here today.

Do you know that is why your forebears left the world, that it was because God had advised his people to gather out from Babylon, gather out from the evils that have afflicted mankind for so long, and come to the tops of these everlasting mountains. When we came here they were so barren and forbidding and desolate that some of those who were in the first company wept when President Young said: "This is the place."
But you sit in this place, and you may go from one end of the world to the other and you will find no other part of the world that is as blessed as has been the part that has been inhabited by the membership of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, not because they were all perfect, but there were enough of them who have kept the commandments of God, that we have been enabled to go on and on and on, and so today you meet in the most remarkable house of worship in the world; you listen to one of the greatest and most wonderful organs; you have listened today to a marvelous choir of sisters. And I might go on and on. And then you go outside of the building and you stand upon one of the most delightful spots that you can find anywhere. These buildings upon this block have not been erected selfishly. They have been built that we might learn the very Ten Commandments that I have been reading to his children.
I did not know I was going to read the Ten Commandments when I stood up here, but I think probably it is profitable to do; we will just think about them, and when we realize that if the people of the world had been keeping the Ten Commandments as I have read them to you today—only a part—I only read just a part—we would not be in the condition we are today, and we would be a much further advanced in all the sciences and the blessings that our Heavenly Father has in store for his children and have not yet come to us.
Blessings of Relief Society
Brethren and sisters, I congratulate the brethren, and I particularly congratulate the sisters that belong to the great Relief Society organization of the Church. There is not any other organization like it, when I realize what you have been doing in the last year or two, gathering means that you might have a doing of your own, that you might worship in if you desire to worship there, that you might transact your business in, a building that you can invite your sisters from all parts of the world to come to and share with you the blessings of our Heavenly Father that have been so richly bestowed upon you.
There are no women in the world blessed as you have been blessed. There are occasionally women who have been marvelously blessed, but when it comes to a community, I know of no other place where women have been blessed as you have been in the communities in which you live.
And so I am happy to be here and so I am today, congratulate you that you are looking forward now to having a building of your own. I think that when that time comes, as possibly it is not very far away, and you are today, I think you will be. And it is not very far away. You have gone out and in a short time have made contributions for the amount that insures a building. Now, you were satisfied with the small building over here that cost a few thousand dollars, eight thousand dollars was the amount the Relief Society put into that building, as I remember it now. How would you like to take that building now and surrender five hundred and fifty-five thousand dollars? You would not think you had made a very good trade, and yet you have
